{{about||the British historian|David Cannadine|the album|David Carradine is a Bounty Hunter Whos Robotic Arm Hates Your Crotch}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Good article}} {{Infobox person | name = David Carradine | image = David Carradine Polanski Unauthorized.jpg | caption = Carradine in April 2008 | birth_name = John Arthur Carradine | birth_date = {{Birth date|1936|12|8}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles, California]], U.S | death_date = {{Death date and age|2009|6|3|1936|12|8}} | death_cause = Accidental ([[Autoerotic fatality|fatal]] [[erotic asphyxiation]]) | death_place = [[Bangkok]], Thailand | body_discovered = [[Swissôtel Nai Lert Park Hotel]] in Bangkok, Thailand | resting_place = [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Hollywood Hills]] | occupation = Actor, director, martial artist | years_active = 1963–2009 | parents = [[John Carradine]]
Ardanelle McCool Cosner | relatives = {{Unbulleted list|[[Keith Carradine]] {{Small|(paternal half-brother)}}|{{nowrap|[[Robert Carradine]] {{Small|(paternal half-brother)}}}}|[[Ever Carradine]] {{Small|(niece)}}|[[Martha Plimpton]] {{Small|(niece)}}}} | spouse = {{Unbulleted list|{{marriage|Donna Lee Becht|1960|1968|end=}}|{{marriage|Linda Gilbert|1977|1983|end=div}}|{{marriage|Gail Jensen|1986|1997|end=div}}|{{marriage|Marina Anderson|1998|2001|end=div}}|{{marriage|Annie Bierman|2004}}}} | partner = [[Barbara Hershey]] {{Small|(1969–1975)}} | children = 3 children, 4 stepchildren | family = [[Carradine family|Carradine]] | website = {{URL|http://www.david-carradine.com}} }} '''David Carradine''' (born '''John Arthur Carradine'''; December 8, 1936 – June 3, 2009) was an American actor, musician, painter and martial artist. He is noted for his leading role as peace-loving [[Chinese martial arts#Shaolin and temple-based martial arts|Shaolin monk]], [[Kwai Chang Caine]], in the television series ''[[Kung Fu (TV series)|Kung Fu]]'' (1972–1975).{{cite news|title=David Carradine family seeks FBI forensic experts help|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/entertainment&id=6847033 |agency=Associated Press Entertainment News |access-date=February 5, 2010}} He was also known for playing [[Frankenstein (Death Race)|Frankenstein]] in ''[[Death Race 2000]]'' (1975) and [[List of Kill Bill characters#Bill|Bill]] in both ''Kill Bill'' films ([[Kill Bill: Volume 1|2003]]–[[Kill Bill: Volume 2|2004]]). He was a member of the [[Carradine family|Carradine family of actors]] that began with his father, [[John Carradine]]. His father's acting career, which included major and minor roles on stage and television, and in cinema, spanned over four decades. A prolific [[B movie|"B" movie]] actor, David Carradine appeared in more than 100 feature films in a career spanning over sixty years.{{cite news| url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/tv-radio-obituaries/5446396/David-Carradine.html| title = David Carradine| date = June 4, 2009| work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]| access-date = June 4, 2009}} He received nominations for a [[Golden Globe Award]] and an [[Emmy Award]] for his work on ''Kung Fu'', and received three further Golden Globe nominations for his performances in [[Woody Guthrie]] biopic ''[[Bound for Glory (film)|Bound for Glory]]'' (1976), the miniseries ''[[North and South (miniseries)|North and South]]'' (1985), and [[Quentin Tarantino]]'s ''Kill Bill: Volume 2'',{{cite web |url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/browse/member/28656 |title=HFPA Awards Search, Nominations & Wins |access-date=June 4, 2009 |publisher=[[Hollywood Foreign Press Association]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120803114941/http://www.goldenglobes.org/browse/member/28656 |archivedate=August 3, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} for which he won the [[Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actor]]. Films that featured Carradine continued to be released after his death. These posthumous credits were from a variety of genres including action, documentaries, drama, horror, martial arts, science fiction, and westerns. In addition to his acting career, Carradine was a director and musician. Moreover, influenced by his ''Kung Fu'' role, he studied martial arts.{{cite news|last=Arnold|first=Laurence|title=David Carradine, Star of T.V.'s Kung Fu, dies at 72|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=aPbN0_ikRnf4&refer=us|publisher=Bloomburg.com|access-date=June 4, 2009|date=June 4, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122224028/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103|archivedate=January 22, 2009|df=mdy-all}}{{cite book|last=Carradine|first=David|title=Spirit of the Shaolin|year=1997|publisher=Charles E. Tuttle|isbn=0804817510}} On April 1, 1997, Carradine received a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]. He was [[#Arrests and prosecutions|arrested and prosecuted]] for a variety of offenses, which often involved substance abuse.Windeler, Robert.''Getting It Together''. (March 21, 1977) People Magazine, Vol.7 No.11 On June 3, 2009, he was found dead in a closet in his hotel room in Bangkok, Thailand due to a [[Autoerotic fatality|fatal]] [[autoerotic asphyxiation]] accident.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=7989893&page=1 |title=David Carradine Autopsy: Died by Auto Erotic Asphyxiation – ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=2009-07-02 |access-date=2014-02-28}} ==Early life== {{main|David Carradine family}} Carradine was born on December 8, 1936, as '''John Arthur Carradine''',{{cite web|url=http://www.ancestry.com|title= California Birth Index, 1905–1995, database on-line|publisher= The Generations Network|location= United States|year=2005|access-date=October 6, 2009}} in [[Hollywood, Los Angeles, California|Hollywood, California]], the oldest child of actor [[John Carradine]] and his wife Ardanelle Abigail (McCool).{{cite web |url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/99/David-Carradine.html |title=David Carradine Biography (1936–)|access-date=July 6, 2008|publisher=Filmreference.com}} He was a half-brother of Bruce, [[Keith Carradine|Keith]], Christopher, and [[Robert Carradine]], and an uncle of [[Ever Carradine]] and [[Martha Plimpton]], most of whom are also actors. Primarily of Irish descent,{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/david-carradines-widow-files-wrongful-death-suit/story?id=10825994|title=Carradine's Widow Files Wrongful Death Suit|first=A. B. C.|last=News|date=June 4, 2010|publisher=}} he was a great-grandson of [[Methodist]] evangelical author [[Beverly Carradine]] and a grandnephew of artist Will Foster.{{cite book|last=Carradine|first=David|title=Endless Highway |year=1995|publisher=Journey}}{{cite web |title=William Frederick Foster, NA, (1883–1953) American Artist |url=http://www.sullivangoss.com/william_frederick_foster |publisher= Sullivan Goss: An American Gallery}} Called "Jack" by his family, Carradine's childhood was turbulent. His parents divorced and repeatedly remarried; he was born to his mother's second marriage of three, and his father's first of four. At the time of Carradine's parents' marriage, his mother already had a son by her first husband, whom John adopted. John Carradine planned a large family, but after his wife had a series of [[miscarriage]]s, he discovered she had had numerous abortions without his knowledge. This rendered her unable to carry a baby to full term. Against this backdrop of marital discord, David almost succeeded in committing suicide[http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2009/06/04/fast-facts-david-carradine-biography/ David Carradine Biography]. FOX. Updated June 4, 2009 by hanging at the age of five. He said the incident followed his discovery that he and his older half-brother, Bruce, who had been adopted by John, had different biological fathers. Carradine added, "My father saved me, and then confiscated my comic book collection and burned it – which was scarcely the point." After three years of marriage, Ardenelle filed for divorce from John, but the couple remained married for another five years."Sued for Divorce," ''Desert News'' (February 4, 1945) p. 8 Divorce finally came in 1944, when Carradine was seven years old. His father left California to avoid court action in the [[alimony]] settlement."Mrs. Carradine Pushes Action Against Actor," ''Los Angeles Times'' (September 4, 1945) p. A12"Actor Goes Free Pending Hearing on Old Charge". ''The Modesto Bee'' (September 5, 1953) p. 4"Carradine Flies East After Court Victory", Los Angeles Times (August 17, 1946) p. A1 After the couple engaged in a series of court battles over child custody and alimony, which at one point landed John in jail, Jack joined his father in New York City. By this time, his father had remarried. For the next few years David was shuffled between boarding schools, foster homes, and reform school. He also would often accompany his father while the elder Carradine performed summer theater throughout the Northeast. Carradine spent time in Massachusetts and even one miserable winter milking cows on a farm in Vermont.Sheridan, Patricia (March 31, 2008) [http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08091/869248-129.stm Patricia Sheridan's Breakfast with David Carradine], ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette'' Eventually, David Carradine returned to California, where he graduated from [[Oakland High School (Oakland, California)|Oakland High School]]. He attended [[Oakland Junior College]] (currently [[Laney College]]) for a year before transferring to [[San Francisco State University|San Francisco State College]], where he studied drama and music theory, and wrote music for the drama department's annual revues while juggling work at menial jobs, a fledgling stage acting career, and his studies. After he dropped out of college, Carradine spent some time with the "[[beatnik]]s"[http://www.mtv.com/movies/person/74249/personmain.jhtml David Carradine Biography]. Accessed Dec. 26, 2009 of San Francisco's [[North Beach, San Francisco|North Beach]] and southern California's Venice. During this time he collected unemployment insurance and sold baby pictures. He was also prosecuted for disturbing the peace. Despite an attempt to [[Draft evasion|dodge the draft]], in 1960 Carradine was inducted into the [[United States Army]], where he drew pictures for training aids. That Christmas he married his high school sweetheart, Donna Lee Becht. While stationed at [[Fort Eustis]], Virginia he helped to establish a theater company that became known as the "entertainment unit."Rabin, Nathin (2004) [http://www.avclub.com/articles/david-carradine,13865/ Interview: David Carradine]. ''The Onion'' He met fellow inductee [[Larry Cohen]], who later cast him in ''[[Q (film)|Q, The Winged Serpent]].''Axemaker, Sean. [http://parallax-view.org/2009/06/04/interview-david-carradine/ Interview-David Carradine]. (2009)Parallax View He also faced [[court-martial]] for shoplifting.Holley, Joe [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/04/AR2009060402049.html "Kung Fu" Star Later Became Tarantino's Villainous "Bill"] (2009) Washington Post In 1962, Donna gave birth to their daughter, Calista. Carradine was honorably discharged[http://www.biography.com/articles/David-Carradine-456272 David Carradine Biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091225034113/http://www.biography.com/articles/David-Carradine-456272 |date=December 25, 2009 }} (2009) Biography Channel Website after a two-year tour. ==Film and television career== ===Early successes=== [[File:Martin Milner Bob Hope Theatre War Eric Kurtz.jpg|thumb|David Carradine (left) and [[Martin Milner]] in the ''[[Bob Hope Presents the Chrysler Theatre|Chrysler Theatre]]'' presentation "The War and Eric Kurtz" (1965)]] Upon leaving the Army, Carradine became serious about his acting pursuits. It was at that time that he was advised to change his name to avoid confusion with his famous father. In 1963, he made his television debut on an episode of ''[[Armstrong Circle Theatre]]''. Several other television roles were to follow including appearances on ''[[Bob Hope Presents the Chrysler Theatre]]'' and ''[[The Alfred Hitchcock Hour]].'' He made his feature film debut in 1964 in ''[[Taggart (1964 film)|Taggart]]'', a western based on a novel by [[Louis L'Amour]]. His first big break, however, came with his second Broadway part in ''[[The Royal Hunt of the Sun]]'', a play by [[Peter Shaffer]] about the destruction of the [[Inca civilization|Inca empire]] by [[conquistador]] [[Francisco Pizarro]]. He said of this performance, "Many of the important roles that I got later on were because the guy who was going to hire me was in that audience and had his mind blown." For that part, Carradine won a [[Theatre World Award]] for Best Debut Performance in 1965.{{cite web | title = Theatre World Awards, 1965–66| url = http://www.theatreworldawards.org/award.html| access-date = June 4, 2009}} With the closing of ''The Royal Hunt of the Sun'', and the failing of his marriage, Carradine left New York and headed back to California. He returned to TV to star in the short-lived series ''[[Shane (TV series)|Shane]]'', a 1966 western based upon [[Shane (novel)|a 1949 novel of the same name]] and [[Shane (film)|previously filmed in 1953]]. Carradine guest-starred opposite [[David McCallum]] in a 1971 episode of ''[[Night Gallery]]'' titled "The Phantom Farmhouse." Also in 1971, Carradine played a hippie reprobate opposite [[Sally Field]] in the well-received television movie ''[[Maybe I'll Come Home in the Spring]]''.{{cite web|url=https://unobtainium13.com/2015/04/21/embracing-the-melodrama-part-ii-39-maybe-ill-come-home-in-the-spring-dir-by-joseph-sargent/|website=Through the Shattered Lens|title=Embracing the Melodrama Part II #39: Maybe I’ll Come Home In The Spring (dir by Joseph Sargent)|author=Bowman, Lisa Marie|access-date=21 April 2015}} In 1972, he co-starred as "Big" Bill Shelly in one of [[Martin Scorsese]]'s earliest films, ''[[Boxcar Bertha]]'', which starred [[Barbara Hershey]], his domestic partner at the time (see Personal life). This was one of several [[Roger Corman]] productions in which he was to appear. It was also one of a handful of acting collaborations he did with his father, John. ===''Kung Fu''=== [[File:David Carradine as Caine from Kung Fu - c. 1972–1975.jpg|thumb|upright|Carradine as Caine.]] For three seasons, Carradine starred as a half-Chinese, half-white [[Shaolin Monastery|Shaolin]] monk, [[Kwai Chang Caine]], on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] hit TV series ''[[Kung Fu (TV series)|Kung Fu]]'' (1972–1975) and was nominated for an [[Emmy Awards|Emmy]] and a [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Award]] for the role. The show, which took place in the [[Old West]], helped, with Bruce Lee movies, to popularize the martial arts and [[Eastern philosophy]] in the west, and immortalized the character of Kwai Chang Caine, also referred to as "Grasshopper," in popular culture. Although the choice of a white man to play the role of Kwai Chang Caine stirred controversy, the show served as steady employment for several Asian-American actors in the U.S.{{cite book| title = The Kung Fu Book of Caine: The Complete Guide to TV's First Mystical Eastern Western| last = Pilato| first = Herbie J| year = 1993| publisher = [[Tuttle Publishing|Charles A. Tuttle]]| location = [[Boston]]| isbn = 0-8048-1826-6}} In addition to [[Keye Luke]] and [[Philip Ahn]], who held leading roles in the cast as Caine's Shaolin masters, [[Robert Ito]], [[James Hong]], [[Benson Fong]], [[Richard Loo]], and [[Victor Sen Yung]] frequently appeared in the series. ''Kung Fu'' ended when Carradine quit to pursue a movie career, but he reprised the role of [[Kwai Chang Caine]] in 1986 in ''[[Kung Fu: The Movie]]''. [[Brandon Lee]], son of [[Bruce Lee]], in his acting debut, portrayed his son. In 1991, he reprised the role of Caine in a cameo appearance in the TV movie ''[[The Gambler (TV movie series)|The Gambler Returns: The Luck of the Draw]]'', in which Caine uses his Chinese friends to help the title character in 1903 San Francisco. Early in the 1990s, Carradine once again reprised the role of Kwai Chang Caine in ''[[Kung Fu: The Legend Continues]]'' (1993–97) playing the grandson of the original character of the same name. Carradine starred in the program and served as executive producer and director. The program offered him the opportunity to recreate the character for which he was most widely recognized. The show was canceled in 1997, after four seasons and 88 episodes. ===Film career=== Immediately following the ''Kung Fu'' series, Carradine accepted the role as the race car driver ''Frankenstein'' in ''[[Death Race 2000]]'' (1975), he said, to "kill the image of Caine and launch a movie career."Carradine, David (1997). ''Spirit of the Shaolin'', Charles Tuttle, p. 49, {{ISBN|0804817510}}. The Roger Corman exploitation film became a cult classic. It was based on [[Ib Melchior]]'s first science fiction work, a short story called ''The Racer''.Kalat, David (2009). ''Death Race 2000''. TCM Underground, Accessed January 14, 2009 Carradine was tapped to play [[Duke Leto Atreides]] in [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]]'s aborted ''[[Dune]]'' adaptation in the late 1970s. [[File:Carradine.jpg|Carradine in April 2005|thumb|upright|left]] In 1976, Carradine earned critical praise for his portrayal of folksinger [[Woody Guthrie]] in [[Hal Ashby]]'s ''[[Bound for Glory (film)|Bound for Glory]]'' (1976) for which he won a [[National Board of Review Award for Best Actor]].[http://www.nbrmp.org/awards/past.cfm?year=1976 National Board of Review Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060516092202/http://www.nbrmp.org/awards/past.cfm?year=1976 |date=May 16, 2006 }}. Nbrmp.org. Retrieved on July 24, 2013. He was also nominated for a Golden Globe Award and [[New York Film Critics Circle Award]] for his role as Guthrie. Carradine worked very closely with his friend, singer-songwriter-guitarist Guthrie Thomas, on the ''Bound for Glory'' film. Thomas assisted Carradine in the guitar style of the period and the songs that had been chosen to be in the film itself. Next came the role of the alcoholic, unemployed trapeze artist Abel Rosenberg in ''[[The Serpent's Egg (film)|The Serpent's Egg]]'' (1977). Set in post-World War I Berlin, ''The Serpent's Egg'', which also starred [[Liv Ullmann]], is together with ''[[The Touch (1971 film)|The Touch]]'' one of the two only English-language films made by legendary [[Sweden|Swedish]] director [[Ingmar Bergman]].Canby, Vincent [https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9F01E3DF1E3EE632A25754C2A9679C946990D6CF The Serpent's Egg Screen: Slouching Toward Berlin: Made in Exile](1978) The New York Times Bergman said of his leading man, "I don't believe in God, but Heaven must have sent him." Carradine said that he and Bergman had plans for further collaboration, but the director's affection for the actor waned when the latter passionately protested a scene that included the butchering of a horse. The altercation caused Carradine to question the fate of Bergman's soul while the director declared, "Little Brother, I am an old whore. I have shot two other horses, burned one and strangled a dog." When Bruce Lee died in 1973, he left an unreleased movie script that he had developed with [[James Coburn]] and [[Stirling Silliphant]] called ''The Silent Flute''. The script became ''[[Circle of Iron]]'' (1978), and in the film, Carradine played the four roles that were originally intended for Lee. Carradine considered this to be among his best work.Searle, Robert (July 14, 2009) [http://www.thehdroom.com/news/Circle_of_Iron_Blu-ray_Review/5250 Circle of Iron Blu-ray Review], thehdroom.comCarradine, David and Moore, Richard "Circle of Iron DVD Extra Feature Commentary" In 1980 Carradine appeared in ''[[The Long Riders]]'' (1980), with his half-brothers [[Keith Carradine|Keith]] and [[Robert Carradine]]. The ensemble cast included three other brother/actor groupings: [[Stacy Keach|Stacy]] and [[James Keach]]; [[Dennis Quaid|Dennis]] and [[Randy Quaid]], and [[Christopher Guest|Christopher]] and [[Nicholas Guest]]. The movie, which was about the [[Jesse James]] gang, gave Carradine, who played [[Cole Younger]], one of his most memorable roles.Johnson, Reed (June 5, 2009) [http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jun/05/entertainment/et-carradine5 The Yin-Yang of David Carradine], Los Angeles Times [[File:Carradine Signing.JPG|thumb|right|Carradine signing autographs in [[Malmö]] in May 2005.]] Throughout most of the 1980s and 1990s, David Carradine's acting career suffered a decline. Although he continued to amass movie and television credits, few of his roles garnered much attention. Most of his work was released straight to video. However, a few of his movies, such as ''[[The Warrior and the Sorceress]]'' (1984), ''[[Sundown: The Vampire in Retreat]]'' (1990) and ''[[Sonny Boy (1989 film)|Sonny Boy]]'' (1989), developed cult followings. In 1989 he starred in the low budget direct-to-video Swedish action movie ''[[The Mad Bunch]]'' directed by [[Mats Helge Olsson]], making him one of three actors (including [[Heinz Hopf (actor)|Heinz Hopf]] and [[Tor Isedal]]) who have starred in both an Ingmar Bergman movie and an Olsson movie.Ekeroth, Daniel (2011) ''[[Swedish Sensationsfilms: A Clandestine History of Sex, Thrillers, and Kicker Cinema]]'', Bazillion Points, {{ISBN|978-0-9796163-6-5}}. In 1997, Carradine was awarded a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]. The presenters played an April Fool's Day prank on him by first unveiling a star bearing the name of his brother, [[Robert Carradine|Robert]].[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8OkyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1QcGAAAAIBAJ&pg=4380,139684&dq=carradine+david&hl=en Being a Carradine can be confusing]. Freelance Star (April 2, 1997), Fredericksburg, Virginia. p. 3A In 2000, he had a small part in the movie ''By Dawn's Early Light''. Carradine enjoyed a revival of his fame when he was cast in Quentin Tarantino's sequential ''[[Kill Bill]]'' movies, in 2003 and 2004. Among those who thought his portrayal of Bill, the assassin extraordinaire, would earn him an Academy Award nomination was [[Scott Mantz]] of ''The Mediadrome'', who said, "Carradine practically steals every scene he's in with confident gusto, and he gives a soulful performance that should all but ensure a spot on next year's Oscar ballot."{{cite web|authorlink=Scott Mantz|author=Mantz, Scott|title=Kill Bill Vol. 2|url=http://www.moviemantz.com/movie_reviews/404/kill_bill2.html | access-date=2010-09-20 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511214245/http://www.moviemantz.com/movie_reviews/404/kill_bill2.html |archivedate=May 11, 2008 |df=mdy|date=2008 }} Roger Ebert and Richard Roeper each had ''Kill Bill Vol. 2'' on their top ten list for of Academy Awards predictions.Szymanski, Mike (December 29, 2004) [http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-7755448_ITM Roeper agree on five for their Top Ten List], ''Knight Rider Tribune'' Although the films received no notice from the Academy, Carradine did receive a [[Golden Globe]] nomination and a [[Saturn Award]] for Best Supporting Actor for his portrayal of Bill. Carradine also appeared as a mysterious martial artist, The Master, in the 2009 DVD premier ''[[Big Stan]]''.IMBD ===Television appearances=== Carradine attracted notice in 1985 when he appeared in a major supporting role in ''[[North and South (TV miniseries)|North and South]]'', a [[miniseries]] about the [[American Civil War]], as the evil and abusive Justin LaMotte. He was nominated for a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Series, Miniseries or Television Film|Golden Globe for Best Supporting Actor]] for his performance. He also appeared in ''[[North and South (TV miniseries)|North and South, Book II]]'', telecast in May 1986. In addition, he was featured in a Lipton Tea commercial, which first aired during the broadcast of [[Super Bowl XXVIII]]. The advertisement paid tribute to [[The Three Stooges]] while satirizing his role in ''Kung Fu''.[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/72222790.html?dids=72222790:72222790&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+31%2C+1994&author=Tom+Shales&pub=The+Washington+Post+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Not+Even+the+Commercials+Were+Super&pqatl=google "Not Even the Commercials Were Super"], ''Washington Post'' (January 31, 1994) In 1999, he made an appearance as the demon Tempus in the Season 1 finale episode of ''[[Charmed]]''. In 2001, he appeared in the episode "The Serpent" of the syndicated TV series ''[[Queen of Swords (TV series)|Queen of Swords]]'' as the sword-wielding bandit ''El Serpiente'' filmed at [[Texas Hollywood]] studios in Almeria, Spain, home of many [[spaghetti western]]s. David also did a guest appearance in episode 11 of ''[[Lizzie McGuire]]'' as himself and also starring his brother Robert who plays Lizzie’s father. David Carradine took over hosting duties from his brother [[Keith Carradine|Keith]] on ''[[Wild West Tech]]'' on the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]], in 2005. The same year he also played both himself and the ghost of a dead man for an episode of the NBC TV show ''[[Medium (TV series)|Medium]]''. By 2006, he had become the spokesperson for [[Yellowbook]], a publisher of independent telephone directories in the United States. He also appeared as the ghost of time, Clockwork, in two episodes of the animated series, ''[[Danny Phantom]]''. He also starred in the 2008 TV movie, ''[[Kung Fu Killer]]'', in which he played a Chinese martial arts master very similar to his ''Kung Fu'' series "Caine" persona—his character in this movie named "White Crane", and mostly referred to or addressed as "C''r''and," frequently spoken with a sort of accent that minimized the R sound.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} ===Posthumous releases=== The actor, who once received an award for being the hardest working member of his profession in Hollywood,[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/david-carradine-a-slice-of-the-action-568334.html Carradine: A Slice of the Action]. (2004)The Independent. Accessed on September 9, 2010. still had approximately a dozen films in "post-production" at the time of his death in 2009. Most of these roles were cameos or small parts in independent, direct to DVD productions. Among them, a horror film, ''[[Dark Fields (2009 film)|Dark Fields]]'' (2009); an action film, ''Bad Cop'' (2009); and a western, ''All Hell Broke Loose'' (2009). Carradine also appeared in a minor role in [[Yuen Woo-ping]]'s Chinese kung fu epic ''[[True Legend]]''. Carradine and Yuen first met while filming ''Kill Bill''. Yuen eulogized Carradine on the ''True Legend'' website, describing him as a "good friend." Yuen said of Carradine: {{quote|He is among the first Hollywood actors to perform Chinese martial arts on the big screen. In real life he is also a genuine kung fu fan, and knows tai chi, qi gong and Chinese medicine. Same as I, people shall always remember his role as Caine, ''the grasshopper'', in ''Kung Fu'', in the '70s, which was a really unforgettable performance. I feel both great honour and regret that ''True Legend'' is one of David Carradine's last works."[http://www.asiaone.com/print/News/Latest%2BNews/Showbiz/Story/A1Story20100208-197290.html Legend in Martial Arts Tale]". ''New Straits Times'' (February 8, 2010).}} One of Carradine's last leading roles was in the period drama ''Golden Boys'', set in 1905. It had only a limited theater run, and received little critical attention.[http://www.justpressplay.net/movie-reviews/929-dvd-reviews/5734-the-golden-boys.html The Golden Boys]. Justpressplay.net (August 18, 2009). Retrieved on 2013-07-24. It was released on DVD shortly after his death. His final released movie was the cult Indy film, ''Night of the Templar'', directed by his friend Paul Sampson, in which Carradine wielded a sword (katana) for the final time on screen. Almost like a foreshadowing, there are several peculiar and eerie references in the film that are coincidental to Carradine's untimely passing which include cross dressing and auto erotic asphyxiation. His last scene on screen ended in the following dialog: "Well, old friend, see you in the next lifetime" / "Yeah, Old Friends, Old Soul Mates" / "Yes, we are." Carradine co-produced a full-length documentary about [[luthier]] [[Stuart Mossman]], which has been identified as the actor's last film appearance.{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.com/movies/777/ |title="The Legend of Stuart Mossman" |access-date=2010-06-27 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812112706/http://www.independent.com/movies/777/ |archivedate=August 12, 2010 |df=mdy }}. ''Santa Barbara Independent''. Accessed June 1, 2010 ''The Legend of Stuart Mossman: A Modern Stradivari'', directed by [[Barry Brown (director)|Barry Brown]], premiered at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival, in February 2010.Brooks, Brian (January 22, 2010) [http://www.indiewire.com/article/premieres_lessons_men_celebritage_heading_to_25th_santa_barbara_film_festiv/ Premieres, “Lessons,” “Men” & Celebritage Heading to 25th Santa Barbara Film Festival], ''IndieWire''. It featured David, Keith, and Robert Carradine performing their music on Mossman guitars. Mossman had appeared with Carradine in ''Cloud Dancer'' (1980), which Brown also directed, and in ''The Long Riders''. On the small screen, Carradine appeared in a guest spot on the television series ''[[Mental (TV series)|Mental]]'' that was broadcast just days after his death. On October 3, 2009, ''[[Celebrity Ghost Stories]]'' premiered on the [[Biography Channel]] with an interview of Carradine discussing his belief that his closet was haunted by his wife's deceased previous husband. The segment, which was described as "eerie," was filmed four months before his own death.Starr, Michael (September 22, 2009) "[http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/tv/item_9RRHKaf3vqK4XClnWkjnzK A Closet Case]", ''New York Post''. In his last of many collaborations with producer Roger Corman, Carradine appeared in the ''Syfy Channel''{{'}}s science fiction monster movie ''Dinocroc Vs. Supergator'', over a year after he died. Ken Tucker, writing for [[Entertainment Weekly]], said the film was "impeccable" and "goofy fun all the way."Tucker, Ken (June 27, 2010) "[http://watching-tv.ew.com/2010/06/27/dinocroc-vs-supergator-review-syfy/ Dinogator Vs. Supergator Review: Dino-mite, Croc-tastic]," ''Entertainment Weekly''. At the time of this release, there were still four more unreleased films that credited David Carradine, including ''[[Stretch (2011 film)|Stretch]]'', which he was filming at the time of his death. ==Directing career== Carradine made his directorial debut on three episodes of ''Kung Fu''. While still performing on ''Kung Fu'', he tried his hand at directing some independent films of his own. [[Americana (1983 film)|''Americana'']] (1983), took ten years to complete due to difficulty in financing. It featured Carradine in the starring role and several of his friends and family members in supporting roles. The film won the People's Choice Award at the [[Director's Fortnight]] at [[Cannes]], but failed to achieve critical support or adequate distribution.Honeycutt, Kurt (June 5, 2009) [https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5541C320090605 Carradine's "Americana" was one from the heart], ''Reuters'' Other directorial attempts included ''You and Me'' (1975), and two unreleased productions: ''Mata Hari'', an epic that starred his daughter, Calista; and a short musical called ''A Country Mile''. ==Martial artist== Carradine knew nothing of the practice of [[kung fu]] at the time he was cast in the role of Kwai Chang Caine; instead, he relied on his experience as a dancer for the part. He also had experience in sword fighting, [[boxing]], and [[street fighting]] on which to draw. For the first half of the original series, David Chow provided technical assistance with kung fu. He never considered himself a master of the art, but rather an "[[Evangelism|evangelist]]" of kung fu. By 2003 he had acquired enough expertise in martial arts to produce and star in several instructional videos on [[T'ai chi ch'uan|T'ai chi]] and [[Qigong]]. In 2005, Carradine visited the [[Shaolin Monastery]] in [[Henan, China]] as part of the extra features for the third season of the ''Kung Fu'' DVDs. During his visit, the abbot, [[Shi Yongxin|Shi Yǒngxìn]], said that he recognized Carradine's important contribution to the promotion of the Shaolin Monastery and kung fu culture, to which Carradine replied, "I am happy to serve."{{YouTube|aEWjJ9nrUm8|"David Carradine's Shaolin Diaries: Back to the Beginning"}}, Season 3 DVD. Warner Video (2005) ==Music career== [[File:DavidCarradineSept06.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Carradine in 2006]] In addition to his acting career, Carradine was a musician. He sang and played the piano, the guitar and the flute among other instruments.Hyatt, Jeff (June 4, 2009) [http://beatcrave.com/2009-06-04/david-carradine/David Carradine Leaves Behind a Musical Legacy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303204030/http://beatcrave.com/2009-06-04/david-carradine/David/ |date=March 3, 2012 }}, ''Beat Crave'' In 1970, Carradine played one half of a flower power beatnik duo in the season 4 ''[[Ironside (TV series)|Ironside]]'' episode "The Quincunx," performing the songs "I Stepped on a Flower," "Lonesome Stranger," and "Sorrow of the Singing Tree." He recorded an album titled ''Grasshopper'', which was released in 1975.[https://www.discogs.com/David-Carradine-Grasshopper/master/443344 Discogs.com master entry on "Grasshopper" album]. Discogs.com. Retrieved on May 31, 2017. His musical talents were often integrated into his screen performances. He performed several of [[Woody Guthrie]]'s songs for the movie ''[[Bound for Glory (film)|Bound for Glory]]''. For the [[Kung Fu (TV series)|''Kung Fu'']] series he made flutes out of bamboo that he had planted on the Warner Brothers lot. He later made several flutes for the movie ''[[Circle of Iron]]'', one of which he later played in ''[[Kill Bill]]''.Carradine, David (2006) ''The Kill Bill Diary''. Harper Carradine wrote and performed the theme songs for at least two movies that he starred in, ''Americana'' and ''[[Sonny Boy (1989 film)|Sonny Boy]]''. The first line from the ''Sonny Boy'' theme, "Paint", which he wrote while filming ''Americana'' in Drury, Kansas, in 1973, is engraved on his headstone.[http://www.radaronline.com/exclusives/2009/12/exclusive-photos-david-carradines-grave-marker David Carradine Grave Marker] December 7, 2009 Radar online He wrote and performed several songs for ''American Reel'' (2003) and wrote the score for ''You and Me''. He and his brother, Robert, also performed with a band, the ''Cosmic Rescue Team'' (also known as ''Soul Dogs''). The band performed primarily in small venues and benefits. ==Personal life== [[File:David Carradine with family in 1987.jpg|thumb|Carradine and his daughter Kansas with wife Gail in 1987]] Shortly after being drafted into the Army in 1960, Carradine proposed marriage to Donna Lee Becht (born September 26, 1937),{{cite book | title = [[Marquis Who's Who|Who's Who in America]] – 2009 | year = 2008 | edition = 63 | access-date = June 4, 2009}} whom he had met while they were students at Oakland High School. They were married on Christmas Day that year. She lived with him off-base in Virginia while he was stationed at Fort Eustis. In April 1962, she gave birth to their daughter Calista. After Carradine's discharge, the family lived in New York while Carradine established his acting career, appearing on Broadway in ''The Deputy'' and ''Royal Hunt of the Sun''. The marriage dissolved in 1968, whereupon Carradine left New York and headed back to California to continue his television and film careers. In 1969, Carradine met actress [[Barbara Hershey]] while the two of them were working on ''[[Heaven with a Gun]]''. The pair lived together until 1975.{{cite news| title = David Carradine, Actor, Is Dead at 72| first = Bruce| last = Weber| date = June 4, 2009| access-date = June 6, 2009| work = [[The New York Times]]| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/05/movies/05carradine.html}} They appeared in other films together, including Martin Scorsese's ''Boxcar Bertha''. In 1972, they appeared together in a nude ''[[Playboy Magazine|Playboy]]'' spread, recreating some sex scenes from ''Boxcar Bertha''.{{cite journal|author=Thal, Ron |date=August 1972|title=Boxcar Bertha|journal=Playboy Magazine|volume=19|issue=8|pages=82–85}} That year, Hershey gave birth to their son, Free (who at age nine changed his name to Tom, much to his father's chagrin). The couple's relationship fell apart around the time of Carradine's 1974 burglary arrest,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aqVOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4voDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7065%2C5915369 |newspaper=Lakeland Ledger |location=(Florida)|title=David Carradine feels typecast as Guthrie |last=Lewis |first=Barbara |date=November 20, 1975 |page=14C}} when Carradine began an affair with [[Season Hubley]], who had guest-starred on ''Kung Fu''. Carradine was engaged to Hubley for a time, but they never married. In February 1977, Carradine married, in a civil ceremony in [[Munich, Germany]], his second wife, Linda (née Linda Anne Gilbert), immediately following the filming of ''The Serpent's Egg''."David Carradine Marries in Munich," ''St. Petersburg Times'' (February 5, 1977) p. 9 Gilbert was previously married to [[Roger McGuinn]] of [[The Byrds]]. Their daughter, Kansas, was born in 1978. Carradine's second marriage ended in divorce, as did the two that followed. He was married to Gail Jensen from 1986 to 1997. She died in April 2010, at the age of 60, of an alcohol-related illness.[http://www.radaronline.com/exclusives/2010/05/exclusive-david-carradines-ex-wife-dies ''David Carradine's Ex-Wife Dies'']. Radar On-line, May 3, 2010. He was married to Marina Anderson from 1998 to 2001. By this time, Carradine had proclaimed himself to be a "serial monogamist."Hay, Carla (April 17, 2009) "David Carradine and Bruce Dern reflect on their golden years." www.examiner.com/article/david-carradine-and-bruce-dern-reflect-on-their-golden-years On December 26, 2004, Carradine married the widowed Annie Bierman (née Anne Kirstie Fraser, born December 21, 1960) at the seaside [[Malibu, California|Malibu]] home of his friend [[Michael Madsen]]. [[Vicki Roberts]], his attorney and a longtime friend of his wife's, performed the ceremony. With this marriage he acquired three stepdaughters, Amanda Eckelberry (born 1989), Madeleine Rose (born 1995), and Olivia Juliette (born 1998) as well as a stepson, actor Max Richard Carradine (born 1998). In one of his final interviews, Carradine stated that at 71, he was still "in excellent shape," attributing it to a good diet and having a youthful circle of friends. "Everybody that I know is at least 10 or 20 years younger than I am. My wife Annie is 24 years younger than I am. My daughter asks why I don't hang with women my age and I say, 'Most of the women my age are a lot older than me!{{'"}}{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/kill-bill/news/carradine-finds-eternal-youth-with-younger-women_1077639|title=Carradine Finds Eternal Youth With Younger Women|date=August 17, 2008|publisher=}} ===Arrests and prosecutions=== By his own account, in the late 1950s, while living in San Francisco, Carradine was arrested for assaulting a police officer. He pled guilty to a lesser charge of disturbing the peace. While in the Army, he faced court-martial, on more than one occasion, for shoplifting.Bennetts, Leslie (September 4, 1975) "Children of the Stars: They do the Strangest Things," ''Miami News'', p. 6 After he became an established actor and had changed his name to David, he was arrested in 1967 for possession of marijuana.Sease, Glean (August 29, 1967). "People." ''The Pittsburgh Press'' At the height of his popularity in ''Kung Fu'', in 1974 Carradine was arrested again,"David Carradine Arrested" (September 19, 1974), ''The Victoria Advocate'', p. 6West, Richard (September 19, 1974) "David Carradine Charged With Attempted Burglary in Rampage," ''Los Angeles Times'' this time for attempted burglary and malicious mischief. While under the influence of [[peyote]], Carradine began wandering nude around his [[Laurel Canyon]] neighborhood. He broke into a neighbor's home, smashing a window and cutting his arm. He then bled all over the homeowner's piano. At some time during this incident he accosted two young women, allegedly assaulting one while asking if she was a witch."Woman Sues, Says T.V. Actor Attacked Her," ''L.A. Times'' (October 23, 1974) p. 1Mtnra, Oliver (July 11, 1975) "David Carradine Ordered to Pay in Assault Suit", ''L.A. Times'', p. 3 The police literally followed a trail of blood to his home."Show Business," ''The Milwaukee Journal'' (September 20, 1974) p. 19. The burglary charges were dropped when nothing was found to be missing. Carradine pleaded no contest to the mischief charge and was given probation."Carradine Fined, Given Probation", ''L.A. Times'' (November 13, 1974) p. 3. He was never charged with assault, but the young woman sued him for $1.1 million and was awarded $20,000. In 1980, while in South Africa filming ''[[Safari 3000]]'' (also known as ''Rally''), which co-starred [[Stockard Channing]], Carradine was arrested for possession of marijuana."South Africans Arrest Carradine," ''Tuscaloosa News'' (September 21, 1980) p. 19 He was convicted and given a suspended sentence."Carradine Guilty in Pot Case," ''Sarasota Times'' (November 13, 1980) p. 12 He claimed that he was framed, in this case, by the [[apartheid]] government, as he had been seen dancing with [[Tina Turner]]. During the 1980s, Carradine was arrested at least twice for driving under the influence of alcohol, once in 1984"David Carradine Arrested in L.A.," ''St. Petersburg Times'' ((May 19, 1984)) and again in 1989. In the second case, Carradine pleaded no contest."David Carradine Gets Jail, Probation For Drunk Driving," ''L.A. Times'' (October 3, 1989) p. 9 Of this incident, the ''Los Angeles Times'' reported: "legal experts say Carradine was handed a harsher-than-average sentence, even for a second-time offender: three years' summary probation, 48 hours in jail, 100 hours of community service, 30 days' work picking up trash for the California Department of Transportation, attendance at a drunk driving awareness meeting and completion of an alcohol rehabilitation program."Finke, Nikki (October 5, 1989) ''Celebrity Justice When Laws Are Broken Fame Isn't The Shield It Used To Be'' L.A. Times, p. 1 In 1994, while in Toronto filming ''[[Kung Fu: The Legend Continues]]'', Carradine was arrested for kicking in a door at [[SkyDome]] while attending a [[Rolling Stones]] concert. When asked his reasoning, Carradine claimed he was worried about getting swarmed by people who recognized him, and so entered the building as quickly as possible.{{cite web|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19941207&slug=1945859|title=Living - Seen, Heard, Said - Seattle Times Newspaper|publisher=}} ==Death== {{wikinews|Kung Fu star Carradine found dead in Bangkok hotel}} [[File:David Carradine Grave.JPG|thumb|upright|left|Grave of David Carradine at Forest Lawn Hollywood Hills]] On June 3, 2009, at the age of 72, David Carradine was found dead in his room at the [[Swissôtel Nai Lert Park Hotel]] on Wireless Road, near Sukhumvit Road, in central [[Bangkok, Thailand]].{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8083479.stm| title = Kung Fu Star Carradine Found Dead| date = June 4, 2009|publisher=BBC News| access-date = June 4, 2009}}{{cite news| url = http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2009/06/04/headlines/headlines_30104421.php| title = David Carradine Found Dead in Bangkok| date = March 6, 2009| work = [[The Nation (Thailand)|The Nation]]| access-date = June 4, 2009| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090607220737/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2009/06/04/headlines/headlines_30104421.php| archivedate = June 7, 2009| df = mdy-all}} He was in Bangkok to shoot his latest film, titled ''[[Stretch (2011 film)|Stretch]]''. A police official said that Carradine was found naked, hanging by a rope in the room's closet, causing immediate speculation that his death was suicide.{{cite news | title = Police: Carradine Found Naked, Hanged in Closet | url = http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=7757144&page=1 | last = Goldman | first = Russell | date = June 4, 2009 | work = [[ABC News]] | access-date = June 4, 2009}}{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/06/04/obit.david.carradine/index.html | title = Actor David Carradine Found Dead | date = June 4, 2009 | publisher=CNN| access-date = June 4, 2009}} However, reported evidence suggested that his death was accidental, the result of [[autoerotic asphyxiation]].Russell Goldman | abc News, Police: Carradine's Death Likely Sex Accident, http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=7763422&page=1, June 5, 2009 Two autopsies were conducted, one involving the celebrity pathologist [[Pornthip Rojanasunan]], and both concluded that the death was not a suicide.{{cite news | work = [[Thai Rath]] | date = June 5, 2009 | title = Forensics pointing out the death of David was autoerotic | url = http://www.thairath.co.th/content/region/10876 | access-date = June 5, 2009|language=th}}{{cite news | title = 'Kung Fu' Star Carradine Dead | url = http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/17906/kung-fu-star-carradine-dead | last = Ngamkham | first = Wassayos | date = June 5, 2009 | work = [[Bangkok Post]] | access-date = June 5, 2009}}{{cite web | title = Carradine Death 'Erotic Asphyxiation' | date = June 6, 2009 | work = [[Bangkok Post]] | url = http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/145219/carradine-likely-died-from-erotic-asphyxiation | access-date = June 5, 2009}}{{cite web | last = Drummond | first = Andrew | title = Kung Fu Star David Carradine Died 'When Auto Erotic Sex Game Went Wrong' | url = http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/2009/06/05/kung-fu-star-david-carradine-died-when-auto-erotic-sex-game-went-wrong-86908-21416527/| date = June 5, 2009 | work = [[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] | access-date = June 5, 2009}} The cause of death became widely accepted as "accidental asphyxiation."Orloff, Brian. [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20289267,00.html ''David Carradine Died of Accidental Asphyxiation'']. (July 2, 2009) People Immediately following his death, two of Carradine's former wives, Gail Jensen{{cite web | last = James| first = Susan Donaldson | title = Ex-Wife Reveals David Carradine's 'Kinky' Habits | url = http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=7793986&page=1 | date = June 9, 2009 | publisher = [[ABC News]] | access-date = June 9, 2009}}{{cite web | title = David Carradine Branded 'Strange' by Ex | url = http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/article/david-carradine-branded-strange-by-ex_1105933 | publisher = [[Contactmusic.com]]| date = June 9, 2009 | access-date = June 11, 2009}} and Marina Anderson,{{cite news | last = McShane | first = Larry | title = David Carradine a Fan of 'Potentially Deadly' Deviant Sex Acts, Ex-Wife Said in Court Papers | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2009/06/05/2009-06-05_david_carradine_death.html | work=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] | date = June 5, 2009 | access-date = June 10, 2009}}{{cite web | last = Darwar | first = Anil | title = Carradine Loved Deadly Sex Games, Says Ex-Wife | url = http://dailyexpress.co.uk/posts/view/106064/Carradine-loved-deadly-sex-games-says-ex-wife | archive-url = https://archive.is/20090613060658/http://dailyexpress.co.uk/posts/view/106064/Carradine-loved-deadly-sex-games-says-ex-wife | dead-url = yes | archive-date = June 13, 2009 | work = [[Daily Express]] | date = June 8, 2009 | access-date = June 10, 2009 | df = mdy-all }} stated publicly that his sexual interests included the practice of [[self-bondage]]. Anderson, who had plans to publish a tell-all book about her marriage to Carradine, said in an interview with ''[[Access Hollywood]]'', "There was a dark side to David, there was a very intense side to David. People around him know that." Previously, in her divorce filing, she had claimed that "it was the continuation of abhorrent and deviant sexual behavior which was potentially deadly."{{cite news | title = Carradine's Ex Says He Had A Dark Side | date = June 8, 2009 | work = [[MSNBC]] | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/31173132/}} Photographs of Carradine at the death scene, as well as photographs of his autopsied body, were circulated in newspapers and on the Internet.Bourke, Philippa (June 9, 2009) [http://www.nationalledger.com/cgi-bin/artman/exec/view.cgi?archive=38&num=26440 "David Carradine Autopsy Photos, Outrage Over Death Photos Expand, FBI Probe"]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''National Ledger'' His family, represented by his brothers, Keith and Robert, pleaded with the public and the press to let them mourn their loved one in peace.Snead, Elizabeth (June 11, 2009) [http://blog.zap2it.com/thedishrag/2009/06/autopsy-report-david-carradine-didnt-kill-himself-more-info-needed.html Keith and Robert Carradine speak of "devastating loss" of David Carradine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100502153951/http://blog.zap2it.com/thedishrag/2009/06/autopsy-report-david-carradine-didnt-kill-himself-more-info-needed.html |date=May 2, 2010 }}. ''Los Angeles Times'' Carradine's funeral was held on June 13, 2009, in Los Angeles. His bamboo casketStickland, Kelly (November 12, 2009).{{cite web|url=http://www.dailycal.org/article/107478/environmentalism_goes_beyond_the_grave |title="Environmentalism goes beyond the grave" |access-date=2009-12-28 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100617195938/http://www.dailycal.org/article/107478/environmentalism_goes_beyond_the_grave |archivedate=June 17, 2010 |df=mdy }} ''The Daily Californian'' was buried at [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park]].{{cite news | title = Stars attend Carradine's funeral BBC News | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8099191.stm | date = June 14, 2009 | access-date = December 30, 2009}} Among the many stars and family members who attended his private memorial were [[Tom Selleck]], [[Lucy Liu]], [[Frances Fisher]], [[James Cromwell]], [[Steve Railsback]], and [[Chris Potter (actor)|Chris Potter]]. His grave was marked on December 3, 2009. The monument proclaimed him to be "The Barefoot Legend" and included a quote from "Paint", a song he wrote and performed as the theme to ''[[Sonny Boy (1989 film)|Sonny Boy]]'', as an epitaph. ===Wrongful death suit=== On the first anniversary of his death, Carradine's widow, Annie, announced that she had filed a lawsuit for wrongful death against the company that produced the film Carradine was working on at the time of his death. The lawsuit claimed that the company failed to provide assistance to the actor that had been agreed upon in his contract. "The suit alleges, the assistant left him behind for dinner on the night before the actor was found dead. The assistant and other film staffers apparently could not reach Carradine and decided to leave without him. Carradine called the assistant an hour later but was told the group was across town, and he would have to make his own arrangements that evening."{{cite web |url=http://www.ktla.com/news/landing/ktla-carradine-lawsuit,0,3371390.story |title="David Carradine's Widow Files Wrongful Death Suit" |access-date=2010-06-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401165237/http://www.ktla.com/news/landing/ktla-carradine-lawsuit%2C0%2C3371390.story |archivedate=April 1, 2012 |df=mdy }}. KTLA.com. (June 4, 2010) Annie Carradine reached a settlement with MK2 Productions in August 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/aug/17/carradines-widow-settles-wrongful-death-suit/|title=Carradine's widow settles wrongful death suit|date=August 17, 2011|work=Associated Press via Washington Times}} She was reported to be receiving about US$400,000 from the company for Carradine's death.{{cite news|url=http://www.laprensa.com.ni/2011/08/19/revista/70348|title=Le siguen sacando|work=La Prensa|date=August 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111117233412/http://www.laprensa.com.ni/2011/08/19/revista/70348|archivedate=November 17, 2011|df=mdy-all}} In June 2010, Marina Anderson, Carradine's fourth ex-wife, published ''David Carradine: The Eye of My Tornado'', a memoir that discusses intimate details of their marriage.Patrick, Dianne (June 10, 2010) "Authors on the Air", ''Publishers Weekly''. ==Filmography== {{Main|David Carradine filmography}} ===Video games=== * ''[[Saints Row]]'' (2006) – William Sharp (voice) ==Awards and honors== * 1966: [[Theatre World Award]], [[Royal Hunt of the Sun]] * 1974: [[TP de Oro]], Spain. Best Foreign Actor, Kung Fu * 1997: Gold Star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]], Television * 1998: Honoree — [[Golden Boot Awards|The 16th Annual Golden Boot Awards]] (along with brothers [[Keith Carradine|Keith]] and [[Robert Carradine|Robert]]) * 2005: ''Action on Film International Film Festival Lifetime Achievement Award'' — First annual recipient{{cite web|url=http://www.aoffest.com/people.html |title=AOF Film International Festival Official Site — People |access-date=2009-06-06 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707152034/http://www.aoffest.com/people.html |archivedate=July 7, 2011 |df=mdy }}. aoffest.com * 2005: [[Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy & Horror Films]], [[Saturn Award]], Best Supporting Actor, ''[[Kill Bill: Volume 2]]'' * 2008: Honoree — [http://www.walkofwesternstars.com/honorees.asp Walk of Western Stars][http://www.walkofwesternstars.com/honorees.asp Walk of Western Stars]. Retrieved on July 24, 2013. ==Bibliography== * {{cite book | title = The Spirit of Shaolin | location = [[Boston]] | publisher = [[Tuttle Publishing]] | isbn = 0-8048-1751-0}} (See [[Shaolin Kung Fu]]) (1991) * {{cite book | title = Endless Highway | location = [[Boston]] | publisher = [[Tuttle Publishing]] | isbn = 1-885203-20-9}} (autobiography, 1995) * {{cite book | title = David Carradine's Tai Chi Workout | url = https://www.amazon.com/David-Carradines-Tai-Chi-Workout/dp/0805037675/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1244668764&sr=1-2#reader | publisher = [[Henry Holt and Company]] | isbn = 0-8050-3767-5}} Co-authored with David Nakahara. (Alternate [[transliteration]] of "T'ai Chi" is [[T'ai chi ch'uan]]) (1995) * {{cite book | title = David Carradine's Introduction to Chi Kung | url = https://www.amazon.com/David-Carradines-Introduction-Chi-Kung/dp/0805051007/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1244662095&sr=1-4#reader | publisher = [[Henry Holt and Company]] | isbn = 0-8050-5100-7}} Co-authored with David Nakahara. (Alternate [[transliteration]] is [[Qigong]]) (1997) * {{cite book | title = The Kill Bill Diary: The Making of a Tarantino Classic as Seen Through the Eyes of a Screen Legend | publisher = [[HarperCollins|Harper Publishing]] | isbn = 0-06-082346-1}} (2006) ==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} * [[Carradine family]] ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|David Carradine}} * {{Official website|http://www.david-carradine.com/|David Carradine}} * {{IMDb name|1016}} * {{IBDB name}} * {{iobdb name|24704}} * {{Tcmdb name}} * {{AllMovie name|id=84255}} * [http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/david-carradine/146366 David Carradine] at [[TV Guide]] * {{Find a Grave|37899069}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070313112648/http://www.avclub.com/content/node/23019 Onion interview] * [http://filmforce.ign.com/articles/506/506238p1.html IGN interview with David Carradine] * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20050411165214/http://www.greencine.com/article?action=view&articleID=117 "A Fresh Thing": David Carradine]'' * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/tv-radio-obituaries/5446396/David-Carradine.html David Carradine] – ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' obituary * [http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-david-carradine5-2009jun05,0,644033.story McLellan, Dennis. {{Infobox person | name = Jason Callahan | image = Jason Callahan.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jason Patrick Callahan | birth_date = {{circa}} April 18, 1976 | birth_place = | disappeared_date = June 1, 1995 | disappeared_place = [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina]] | death_date = {{death date and given age|1995|6|26|19}} | death_place = [[Emporia, Virginia]], United States | death_cause = [[Blunt-force trauma]] following a [[vehicle accident|vehicular accident]] | body_discovered = | resting_place = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = "Grateful Doe," "Jason Doe" | organization = | known_for = Former [[unidentified decedent]] | home_town = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | website = {{URL|https://www.facebook.com/GratefulDoe}} <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> }}
'''Jason Patrick Callahan''' (April 18, 1976 – June 26, 1995), previously known as '''Grateful Doe''' and '''Jason Doe''', was an [[Americans|American]] man killed in a car accident on June 26, 1995, in Emporia, Greensville County, Virginia. His body remained nameless until December 9, 2015.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.wmbfnews.com/story/30708764/dna-positively-identifies-grateful-doe-as-man-missing-from-myrtle-beach | title=DNA positively identifies 'Grateful Doe' as man missing from Myrtle Beach | work=WMBF News | date=9 December 2015 | agency=NBC | accessdate=December 9, 2015}}</ref><ref name=bizarre>{{cite web|title=10 Bizarre Unidentified Body Cases|url=http://www.alistaday.com/10-bizarre-unidentified-body-cases/|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=7 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=namus>{{cite web|title=Case Report – NamUs UP # 6095|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/6095|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=23 October 2009}}</ref><ref name=bodies>{{cite web|last1= Moramarco|first1=Steve|title=8 Mysterious Dead Bodies|url=http://www.oddee.com/item_98950.aspx|website=oddee.com|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=6 May 2014}}</ref> Earlier in 2015, photographs of an unknown male surfaced on a Facebook page for the John Doe. DNA testing later confirmed Callahan to be the unidentified man.<ref name=li/><ref name="identified2">{{cite news | url=http://wbtw.com/2015/12/09/dna-identifies-grateful-doe-as-missing-myrtle-beach-man-20-years-after-disappearance/ | title=DNA identifies ‘Grateful Doe’ as missing Myrtle Beach man 20 years after disappearance | work=WBT News 13 | date=9 December 2015 | agency=Media General Communications Holdings | accessdate=December 9, 2015 | author=Brown, Jo}}</ref>
==Death==
Callahan was killed in a vehicle crash, along with the driver, Michael Hager, after the [[Vanagon]] in which they were riding crashed into a pair of trees on [[U.S. Route 58]] West around 1:30 PM on June 26, 1995.<ref name=jason>{{cite web|title=Jason ‘Grateful’ Doe|url=http://jasonbrumley.wordpress.com/2010/09/20/32/|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=20 September 2010}}</ref><ref name=nameless>{{cite news|last1=Lohr|first1=David|title=Grateful Dead Fan Remains Nameless, 18 Years After Fatal Crash|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/25/grateful-doe_n_5208512.html|accessdate=5 September 2014|agency=[[Huffington Post]]|date=25 April 2014}}</ref><ref name=ncmec>{{cite web|title=John Doe 1995|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1104361/1#poster|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]]|accessdate=5 September 2014}}</ref><ref name=ginny>{{cite web|title=Grateful Doe, Caledonia Jane: Ask the Question|url=http://gonemissinginny.com/2012/12/31/grateful-doe-caledonia-jane-ask-the-question/|website=gonemissinginny.com|accessdate=25 September 2014|date=31 December 2012}}</ref> Neither man was wearing a seat belt, which likely contributed to each of their deaths.<ref name=doe/><ref name=listverse>{{cite web|last1=Warder|first1=Robin|title=10 Mysterious Cases Involving Unidentified People|url=http://listverse.com/2013/06/14/10-mysterious-cases-involving-unidentified-people/|website=listverse.com|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=14 June 2014}}</ref> Found with Callahan's body were two [[Grateful Dead]] tickets from [[Washington, D.C.]], which had been [[ticket scalping|scalped]], a dollar in quarters, and a yellow [[BIC lighter]]. A letter was found, depending on sources either in the John Doe's pocket or near the crash site, reading: ''Jason, Sorry we had to go, see ya around, call me #914-XXXX. Caroline T. & Caroline O. Bye!!!!''. The phone number on the letter lacked an area code and never led to any additional clues. The letter also contained a small drawing that some speculate may be of [[Jerry Garcia]].<ref name=nameless/><ref name=blog/> The tickets were dated June 24, 1995, and June 25, 1995, respectively.<ref name=doe/> Neither of the 'Carolines' have ever been identified.<ref name=griffin/>
==Physical description==
[[File:Grateful_Doe_tattoo.jpg|thumb|left|Photo showing Jason Callahan's tattoo]]
The young man, estimated to be between the ages of fifteen and twenty-one years old, had brown eyes with long curly brown or dark blond hair that had been dyed a reddish color.<ref name=blog>{{cite web|title=Grateful Dead Fan – Jason Doe|url=http://uidmysteries.blogspot.com/2013/02/grateful-dead-fan-jason-doe.html|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=25 February 2013}}</ref> There was a [[tattoo]] of a star on his upper-left arm and another possible tattoo, which was faded, on his right arm, both of which appeared to have been amateurishly executed. He was wearing a beaded necklace and his left ear had been [[ear piercing|pierced]] but he did not wear an earring.<ref name=ncmec/><ref name=doe>{{cite web|title=Case File: 127UMVA|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/127umva.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=5 September 2014}}</ref> There was a scar found on his back.<ref name=namus/> He was a Caucasian, had no apparent dental work as his third molars were visible. However, his teeth were fairly well cared for.<ref name=jason/><ref name=doe/> At the time of the accident he was wearing a red, [[tie-dye]]d Grateful Dead T-shirt, [[Levi (company)|Levi's]] jeans, white [[socks]] and black [[Fila (company)|Fila]] [[running shoes]].<ref name=namus/><ref name=jason/>
==Investigation==
[[File:Grateful Doe note.jpg|thumb|150px|Note written by "Caroline O." and "Caroline T."]]
The vehicle's driver was identified as Michael E. Hager, 21, who may have picked the John Doe up as a hitchhiker, and who authorities hypothesize may have fallen asleep at the wheel, as neither of the decedents had [[drugs]] or [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]] in their bodies.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gettys|first1=Travis|title=South Carolina woman reports son missing 20 years after he left home to follow Grateful Dead|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2015/01/south-carolina-woman-reports-son-missing-20-years-after-he-left-home-to-follow-grateful-dead/|accessdate=17 January 2015|work=RawStory|date=15 January 2015}}</ref> It has been suggested that Hager may have agreed to transport the John Doe because of their similar styles of dress, as they both appeared to be fans of The Grateful Dead.<ref name=nameless/> Authorities attempted to identify the John Doe through fingerprint analysis with the aid of national databases, but were unsuccessful.
When interviewed, Hager's family could not identify the unknown passenger, who had been reported to have been riding in Hager's [[Volkswagen Vanagon]] when he stopped to give his father a letter in [[Williamsburg, Virginia]].<ref name=listverse/><ref name=blog/> However, a detective from the area stated that this claim was not accurate, and that Hager was alone when he stopped to visit his father.<ref name=nameless/> It is speculated that the unidentified young man had actually been picked up between [[Fairfax, Virginia|Fairfax]] and [[Gloucester, Virginia]].
Due to the severity of the lacerations on John Doe's face, mortuary photographs could not be released to the public, although a facial reconstruction was later released.<ref name=nameless/> In 2012, another facial reconstruction was created by the [[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]]. The man who had originally bought the tickets found in John Doe's pocket did not remember the person he had sold them to.<ref name=doe/> At least 221 missing people were ruled out as possible identities of the victim.<ref name=namus/>
==2015 developments==
[[File:Jason Callahan with reconstruction.jpg|thumb|left|Image of Callahan (left) compared to a reconstruction created by the [[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]]]
In 2015, photographs surfaced of a young man wearing similar clothing to that worn by the John Doe and who bore a strong resemblance to the reconstruction images. The person in these photographs was named Jason and was described to have been a fan of Grateful Dead. He had not been heard from since 1995 and was known to have lived in both Illinois and South Carolina. It had not yet been verified whether this was indeed the John Doe as his former roommates and other friends did not recall Jason's last name.<ref name=griffin>{{cite news|last1=Griffin|first1=Courtney|title='Grateful Doe' may have ties to Myrtle Beach|url=http://www.carolinalive.com/news/story.aspx?id=1147316#.VLCQgCvF_Tp|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=Carolina Live|date=9 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UPDATE: Imgur, you may have helped identify 'The Grateful Doe'.|url=http://imgur.com/gallery/vfXjr|publisher=Imgur|accessdate=3 January 2015|date=2 January 2015}}</ref> The ''[[New York Post]]'' and [[BuzzFeed]] were some of the newspapers that covered the story.<ref name=li/><ref>{{cite web|title=Interwebs Now May Be Close To Solving A 20-Year-Old Cold Case Need Public’s Help|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/lrutley/interwebs-now-closer-to-solving-a-20-year-old-cold-x024|website=buzzfeed.com|publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]|accessdate=8 January 2015}}</ref>
In January 2015, law enforcement conducted a DNA test to see if the John Doe was the same man as Jason Patrick Callahan, the son of a 63-year-old woman who had not seen or heard from him since June 1995, when he left home to "follow the Grateful Dead".<ref>{{cite news|title=Woman Reports Deadhead Son Missing Since '95|url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/documents/bizarre/grateful-doe-case-768391|accessdate=17 January 2015|date=14 January 2015}}</ref> Callahan, who was identified as the young man in the photographs, is described as having been a white male with wavy blonde hair and brown eyes, standing between {{convert|5|ft|10|in|m|abbr=off|sp=us}} and {{convert|6|ft|m|2|abbr=off|sp=us}} tall, and weighing about {{convert|160|lb|kg|abbr=off|-1}}. Callahan, if he was alive, would have been 38 at the time.<ref name=myrtle>{{cite news|last1=Root|first1=Tonya|title=Myrtle Beach police investigate missing person case, possible link to ‘Grateful Doe’|url=http://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/2015/01/14/4726665_myrtle-beach-police-investigate.html?sp=/99/209/&rh=1|accessdate=15 January 2015|work=Myrtle Beach Online|date=14 January 2015}}</ref> Callahan was not reported missing by his mother until 2015.<ref name=li>{{cite news|last1=Li|first1=David K.|title=Mom reports son missing 20 years after he left to follow Grateful Dead|url=https://nypost.com/2015/01/15/mom-reports-son-missing-20-years-after-he-left-to-follow-grateful-dead/|accessdate=17 January 2015|date=15 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Mom reports son missing since 1995, says he left home to follow the Grateful Dead band|url=http://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/2015/01/14/4726665_myrtle-beach-police-investigate.html?sp=/99/209/&rh=1|accessdate=15 January 2015|work=Sun News|date=14 January 2015}}</ref>
Lt. Joey Crosby, spokesman for Myrtle Beach police, stated that Callahan's mother failed to file a report with police due to the nomadic nature of Grateful Dead fans. "She attempted to report it when he went missing but didn’t know which jurisdiction to report it to," he said.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myhorrynews.com/news/crime/article_31d4be00-9c0e-11e4-8f85-fb52546762a0.html|title=Myrtle Beach police investigate possible link between missing man, "Grateful Doe"|work=MyHorryNews.com|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref> Callahan's family also stated that they presumed he had gone to "live on his own, elsewhere."<ref name=identified2/>
After initial tests proved inconclusive, additional DNA testing confirmed that the body was indeed that of Jason Callahan.<ref name=li/><ref name="identified2"/><ref>{{cite news|title="Julie Doe" - Transgender woman likely murdered in 1988, believed to be cisgender for 27 years|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2015/11/19/1451910/--Julie-Doe-Trans-woman-likely-murdered-in-1988-believed-to-be-cis-for-27-years|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=Nov 19, 2015}}</ref>
